newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa minister to meet business, labour on bill.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa minister to meet business, labour on bill.

text.p: Labour Minister Tito Mboweni would meet business representatives later on Tuesday to discuss controversial labour legislation which sparked a one-day national strike in June, the labour ministry said.
It said in a statement the meeting would be followed by a meeting on Wednesday between Mboweni and the leadership of the 1.9-million-member Congress of South African Trade Unions.
Meetings with the National Council of Trade Unions and the Federation of Unions of South Africa were also planned.
"Through these meetings the Ministry aims to discuss and explore areas of possible agreement on the Basic Conditions of Employment Bill," the statement said.
The bill was approved by cabinet in April but still has to be passed by parliamnet.
It has been the subject of ongoing clashes between labour and business, with Cosatu staging a one-day national work stoppage on June 2 to pressure business to revise its position.

The federation has threatened fresh national strikes in August to reinforce its demands for a 40-hour working week to be phased in over not more than five years, six months maternity leave of which at least four are paid and double payment for Sunday work.
Business is concerned about the bill's wide scope and provisions which could raise employment costs to the point of creating obstacles to new jobs.
